Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2011 09:36AM - edited Jan 4, 2011 09:56AM by UTMom2014 Hi everyone, I just had my left breast aspirated because of hardness and swelling following my lumpectomy on Dec.14.  I'm so glad for all the info here from everyone because I've been concerned about preventing lympedema.  I was doing the recommended exercises and even saw a physical therapist about this.  Now I see that rest is required, though I find this a bit confusing.  I'm planning to lay low for a week regarding exercise, but planned to go back to work tomorrow.  That involves typing all day.  Does anyone know if that's a good idea or not?  Yes, I also plan to call my doctor about it.  Thanks in advance and good luck everyone.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy now a seroma? Info needed gogators sunangel27

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2011 06:21PM UTMom2014 wrote: Hello everyone, it's day two post FEC one.  Went out to dinner last night with my sister and was so happy to feel "normal" I got carried away. For anyone prone to gastric/acid reflux troubles, Pappadeaux may not be the best choice!  I had a single crabcake and was unhappy with the aftereffects.  Nothing from the chemo, all acid but neutralized finally with Malox.  Did walk yesterday (2 miles) but less today(3/4 mile).  Feeling slower overall, not interested in food but have downed two protein shakes and am having a raw vegetable juice for energy and vitamins.  Julie H: I was given EMEND in a drip and told it would stay in my system 5 days, but I had break through nausea from the beginning.  It's true, taking the anti-nausea meds on time is better than after you need it.  I've experienced that already, though today was great that way because I did it on time.  I'm hoping to go to work tomorrow but will see how my energy feels.  Proud-Mom:I read about fasting somewhere on this site, if not this thread.  I haven't researched it very much.  You can't go wrong checking with your own doctor.  I have just under three weeks before my next chemo and hope to learn more before making up my mind.  One of my other threads I follow is the marathon runners one under fitness.  Those ladies really inspired me to do something, even at my slow pace due to knee surgery a couple years ago.  I have since learned on this site that studies show bc patients who exercise, no matter how moderately, bounce back faster, have better energy levels, and can reduce recurrence by up to 40-50%.  If I find the study, I will post it.  That is what made me determined to try:D  I know there will be days I won't be up to it, but even a little helps and that gives me hope.  Good luck to all; I will see how days 3-5 go and pray for low side effects!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2011 03:13PM UTMom2014 wrote: Today was day 3 after my first chemo/FEC.  Today was not so great; had problems with constipation and still can't eat food.  I guess that's going to be part of my cross to bear, no solids for a few days.  Left work at noon after trying a little chicken and rice soup, the gastric upset wrecked my energy and sent me to bed.  I felt better after a nap and a yogurt cup; energy somewhat restored.  Guess I will stick to protein shakes and yogurt; developing a distrust of food.  I pray tomorrow is better, otherwise I won't even consider getting up for work.  I thought my problem with dinner Sat night was it was breaded and fried.  Even tender chicken (two bites), rice (one spoonful) and veggies (couple pieces of carrots and squash) were too much.  Anyone else react like that to food?  WarriorPrincess: I had tearing eyes during the treatment and then again at home one day later.  Was ok while facing my computer at work today, but I don't know if that will be happen again or not.    Hope everyone is doing better...
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2011 05:58PM UTMom2014 wrote: Thanks Julie H and MaryMeg:  feeling better now.  I'll just have to take food slowly and try to get in another protein milk shake w/fruit in it tonight.  I've only got to about 600 calories, too low.  I'm ER+, and the articles below talk about the benefit of moderate exercise to bc patients.  I'm 50, slightly overweight, with long term knee problems.  In my 20's and 30's, jogging was fun, but walking at 3 mph was more my speed within the last few years.  Being overweight led me to develop serious knee problems.  After knee surgery, I was once again walking about 3 mph, about 3 miles or so 5 days a week.  While recovering from the lumpectomy, I learned a lot from older chemo threads where people referred to the importance of exercise.  That led me to discuss it with my surgeon and onco, who approved and also sent me to a physical therapist who also supports moderate exercise, for me at this time in my life and my specific needs. Post lumpectomy and chemo, I'm walking at maybe 1.5 to 2 mph speed, which is quite slow.  I stay in my neighborhood, because I want to be near if I tire or need the restroom.  We are about to get cold and rainy, so I'll prob. stick to the treadmill for a few minutes if possible when I can.  Hope these articles help anyone interested in the benefits of moderate exercise through chemo.  A doctor's advice is important, esp. at a time like this.  Exercise was the last thing on my mind when I got diagnosed, it was only the wealth of wisdom and experience on this site that got me headed in that direction.    http://www.livestrong.com/article/94144-exercise-breast-cancer/ http://www.livestrong.com/article/55159-statistics-breast-cancer-recurrence/ http://breastcancer.about.com/od/riskfactorsindetail/a/exercise_bc.htm http://ww2.cancer.org/docroot/NWS/content/NWS_1_1x_Exercise_Can_Improve_Breast_Cancer_Survival.asp
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2011 06:31PM UTMom2014 wrote: TGIF, I'm ready for some down time.  Glad to hear so many of you are also feeling better:D  SE's are still mild, constipation (lots of water helps; added physllium husk to my bkfst shake), no sores but not quite right (Biotene 3-4 x's a day), nausea (still taking 8 hrs meds), sporadic tiredness at work (but able to do full days since Wed-day 5 post FEC).  Sure hope this is it, though I notice I really don't want to exercise.  I got a mile in yesterday and will attempt it again tonight.  Thanks for the (electronic) cookies and milk Annie!  I had two servings of Rocky Road tonight, wasn't quite the same but pretty good anyway.  I too lost about 5 pounds since the chemo, so I'm feeling decidely not guilty about that.  There is a little nagging voice in the background asking if this much sugar can be good at a time like this.  But like Scarlett used to say, "I'll think about that tomorrow"!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 04:34AM - edited Jan 16, 2011 06:17AM by UTMom2014 Hello all!  Got past the pity party over the period, which I thought was a thing of the past, talk about a surprise.  Just wanted to say MaryMeg that one upside to reaching "celebrity" status in your area is that there will always be a ready hand/shoulder around should you ever face any sort of physical challenges.  I know in my office of almost 200, people show such kindness, though I haven't talked to everyone about it, but somehow everyone seems to know.  Once the hair, eyebrows and eyelashes go, it will be impossible to keep private about it anyway, lol!  For slcst12 and anyone starting out here, just wanted to post a link to a list of supplies and supplements that our bc sisters have found useful. I stocked my chemo box and daily supply bag from it, though I learn from everyone here almost everyday too.  http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/69/topic/706846?page=2#idx_31 Jane I'm 9 days post 1 of 4 FEC, but I'm doing 12 Taxol afterward.  The first one seemed fairly uneventful, though constipation and nausea have been a constant.  Having the treatment on Friday afternoon allowed me to return to work on Monday, but I ate food too soon on that day and ended up going home from the acid/gastric problems.  For me, protein milkshakes and yogurt were best those first five days.  My exp. with the food has led me to take it one bite at a time, after which I wait a bit to see if it feels safe to continue with more.   I'm asking my onco Monday about Taxol vs. Taxotere; it would be nice to understand why he chose that for me.  Melissa : Thanks for posting your post-hair photo.  You guys look great, and what a great guy you have Melissa!  I'm borrowing courage from everyone here because that's the next "phase" to deal with for me. Jane your hair sounds so beautiful; mine never gets beyond shoulder length, too hot and humid where I live!  Good to know about protecting the follicles, hadn't seen that before.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 05:27PM UTMom2014 wrote:
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 08:16PM UTMom2014 wrote:
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 05:39PM UTMom2014 wrote: Well, another first in this journey of twists and turns.  Puked my guts out while walking even though I'd taken a Zophran today.  I never vomited after my first chemo.  But I blame myself though, since I strayed from my shakes and yogurts and ended up having about 2/3 cup mashed potatoes.  Wonder if I loaded them down with too much butter; either way my stomach has calmed so in a way it was a good thing. It felt like a cement mixer in there for a few hours.  I'm going to be so ready for solid food by day 6 or so, if I can hold back that long:D  Sorry you've had a rotten time too Moe and MaryMeg.  JulieH kudos for getting your head shaved; I couldn't do it and with all the fallout after my buzz, I wish I had.  Still, caps or wig on at all times helps with the messiness, even though my scalp still feels pretty sensitive. Wendi it is tough to get used to, but for me the white blood count problem and getting on with #2 ended up overshadowing the wierdness of losing the hair.   It's almost all gone now.  Well guys, I don't have to go in until noon tomorrow, so it'll be nice to take it slow in the morning.  Hope all of you have a good start to your week.  {{{{{Hugs}}}}} to all
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 05:07PM UTMom2014 wrote: Just got back from doctor's checkup.  Labs showed my WBC down to below 2, and this is after a Neulasta 5 days ago.  He said this is probably the lowest I'll get, and asked if I was tired (Yeeees).  Now I'm doing this weekly so he can check on me.  I'm allowed to go to work but not allowed to hug/kiss friends, family and strictly no crowds.  Anyone else feeling tired day 3-6 where it coincides with low WBC?   Thinking of all you guys, but most esp. those coping with this disease AND a blizzard.  Even down here along the U.S./Mex border, we're freezing tonight and tomorrow.  My office may call a non-work day.  I know, we're suuuuch sissies but are expecting ice, sleet and possibly snow flurries.  Lowest it should get is the mid 20's though.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2011 04:17PM UTMom2014 wrote: Deleted previous post b/c it struck me as waay too morbid after the fact.  Feeling down lately, things not going well.  Would love one good week, but it's been a while. Can't believe I have 9 more weeks of Taxol yet.  Think I'll refrain from commenting until my mood/health improves.  I just want to wake up a little closer to "done".  Wishing everyone strength and improved health.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: May 23, 2011 11:53AM UTMom2014 wrote: Oh BDavis, what a time you are having.  Is your son out of the hospital?  As for the daughter and the car, thank goodness you have all that backup.  Sometimes when it rains it pours.  Congrats again to everyone finishing up chemo!  Lots of celebrations in order:D JulieH thanks for the radiation details, that's the next step for me as well. Will pray your DH gets good news.  Lorenar, how did the car situtation work out? Where is that light at the end of the tunnel?  I can't see it from here either!  Going through setback #6, with whites too low to permit chemo on time.  Was going to be done mid June, now so far back and no reason to expect this won't keep happening after each Taxol. Understand bone marrow is shot and they have to give me an extra week rest time between chemos, plus Neupogens to boost white blood cell production.  Have come to accept that all I can do is be patient, nothing to be gained from overthinking/overworrying this.  My lowest to date was .04 but grateful that haven't had to return to the hospital.  Also, I think I'm done being frustrated at how long this will drag on.  Reading this site and talking to my fellow BC's at the clinic never fails to inspire me. Did anyone experiece a skin reaction--like a rash--while on Taxol?  I've got a stain-looking patch on my upper back that gets quite itchy at times. I see that many of you are starting to spurt hair.  Surprisingly, my head is now covered in soft stubble, and I feel it on my legs enough to shave them again.  Strangely, the eyebrows/eyelashes continue to disappear.  You would think if it's coming back elsewhere they would hold up there too?  Is there any understanding any of this???? Thanks in advance for any feedback.  Off to get that wonderful Neupogen, (ouch!)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2011 07:53PM UTMom2014 wrote: It's over, thanks for keeping an eye on me ProudMom and anyone still checking in here!  Had the last infusion last Monday, will check the wbc on Monday but all seems to be ok.  Just wanted to mention that I had a bone scan done this week at MD Anderson in Houston, among other things.  It appears that the walking through the chemo helped the bones so that there was no bone loss.  Am told to keep it up through radiation and Tamoxifen, since those therapies can also cause bone loss. I hope everyone is well; if memory serves some from this group may even be done with rads by now.  I don't start until Aug. 15th.  Thanks everyone for all the help and support; it feels so good to finally be done.  Hugs and well wishes to all.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2011 11:03PM - edited Jan 6, 2011 11:14PM by UTMom2014 JulieH: Thanks so much for remembering.  Can't sleep from worrying about it.  Did go to work today, four days after port placement.  Best medicine in the world, I must say.  I think I threw up every day this week except today, so the distraction of work really was what I needed.  I'm planning on working tomorrow right up to my chemo appt, go home for my daughter, change into something comfy and warm (my dr's office is a freezer), then off to my appt.  Moe0279: So glad to know about using the EMLA cream an hour before with a bit of plastic wrap to keep it on your chest.  My onco nurse, who happens to be my sister, also says people really like that.  JeanH: Thanks for the hard candy tip, I'll be taking that along with water and popsicles to my appt.  Everything I read about FEC scares me, but it's effective, so I'll have to grin and bear it.  Already got a wig.  There's lots of places online to browse through. However the style I liked was out of stock, luckily a local shop carried it and it was perfect for me.  Not too fluffly and a good length.  My hairdresser was wonderful about layering it a bit to look more like me.  Turns out his 86 year old mom survived a masectomy 5 yrs ago, and his dad is dealing with cancer also now.  He was so compassionate and kind.  I'm going back to get buzzed in about a week or so.  Would rather take control than watch it melt off me.  Good luck everyone, you guys are in my thoughts and prayers also.  I'm hoping for the best but I'll have all my chemo supplies at the ready, just in case:D
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2011 02:52AM - edited Jan 8, 2011 02:56AM by UTMom2014 Well everyone, I'm no longer a chemo virgen!  The process took longer than I expected (arrived at 2pm left at 6:45pm).  Had a mild dizzy reaction to the Cytoxan in FEC and the bag was slowed down--reaction disappeared.  Got home and did a 2 mile walk.  Other than one Ex-lax tab to prevent constipation and two Tums for the heartburn that followed, I didn't take any other meds last night; felt fine overall until 4am this morning. I have a low grade headache and mild nausea, so I've started my break-through meds for that to stay ahead of it, even though the Emend I was given is to be in my system 5 days or so.  Overall I slept well though.  I so wish I'd read about fasting 48 hours before chemo.  The 1300+ calories I consumed yesterday include a chicken salad sandwich during the time there. I bet I didn't need to do that to myself.  If it helps prevent nausea, fasting will be worth it.  I'll see how I get through the weekend and the workweek. BTW, once I got my diagnosis I got back on a calorie counter, the one at LiveStrong.com.  I'm really concerned about getting enough calories on the bad days, though I suppose there's not much I can do about it if I'm off food a few days.  Will try to post later, nausea has subsided about 80% while writing this
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 11:15AM UTMom2014 wrote: Your post made me want to cry from releif, Momand2kids; I love when those who have got through to the other side of this monster come over to pep us up.  It's a huge kindness to remind us that this too shall pass. I got a hint of a period today, which explains the low back pain and tiredness the last two days.  Wasn't expecting it and had fears something was "going wrong" despite all my best efforts.  It's nothing like the normal one, but the timing is spot on.  Will cont. to take it easy today and forget about trying to exercise.  Just doing little things around the house will have to do.  Hope everyone has a good day.  Getting my hair cut also this weekend; wig is ready to go and I even got a beautiful free Gaila hat this week.  Don't know if I'll have the guts to shave it off; may just leave it super short {{{{cringe}}}}. I'll try not to get as weepy as I got wig-shopping but not feeling particularly brave today.  Must be the period, or our cold dreary day.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 05:28PM UTMom2014 wrote:
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 10:25AM UTMom2014 wrote: Phase I: FEC X4 @ 3 wks/#3 next Thursday;Phase II: Taxol X12 @week  Hi Melissa, you have my sympathies regarding the period.  I got it about 7 days after FEC#1 and it complicated my life because it came during hospital visit #1 for low WBC.  It was heavier and one day longer than usual.  I also got really bad cramps and lower back pain, not unusual for me but just more of it.  Like JulieH, I also had hemorroids from constipation.  Overall it made for one of the most challenging weeks so far.  All you can do sometimes is just concentrate on one day at a time and getting through it.  Has your dr ok'd a painkiller for cramps?  As for trying to have a "normal" day, my advice is let all that go for the moment and give your body the rest and care you need.  Just think that once you are well, there will be lots of normal years ahead for you and your family.  Feel better. baf4292: You're welcome, and great choice!  I like the cute style, it seems to be a close match to how you wear your hair in your avatar.  I agree that liking the wig makes a big difference.  The quality is really nice too; in fact my wig behaves much better than my normal hair does and I really do love mine also!  It's nice to have some things work out as we get through this stuff.  webu: I prefer to call mine chemo fog, because fog leaves after a little while!  I def have had bouts with that, especially the first week or so after the treatment.  I guess 6 hours of that cocktail gets all over the place.  I'm slower on projects at work, and I sometimes go to the kitchen 3 times before I remember what it was I needed.  From reading older posts from previous years, the scariest chemo fog story I heard was someone who forgot how to drive home.  I'm lucky my daughter worries so much about me she drives me to work for about a week afterwards in case I'm too tired to handle it.  I wish it wasn't necessary to have turned her life on it's side for six months, but I couldn't do this on my own, def. not the trips to the hospital.  And heaven help me if I forget the way home someday .  JuleH: Glad you are feeling better!  Lucky for you that Valentine's Day falls on a good day.  May you have many, many healthy birthdays to celebrate once this one is done:D  I'm also taking advantage of my last few "good" days before next Thursday gets here to eat as I like.  On the bright side, it will be 3 down 1 to go after this one.  Is anyone else planning a celebration once chemo is over?  I am sooooo looking forward to that day.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2011 03:48PM UTMom2014 wrote: Thanks JeanH.  I don't know much about radiation yet, but glad to know that there's an option like that.  Going to go look for that mascara you mentioned too. Had another wbc set back; so on hold this week, with two chemos ahead still.  Hope everyone has a great weekend.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2011 04:09PM UTMom2014 wrote: JulieH about the joints issue, did you ever do the L-Glutamine powder during Taxol? I am still on it and it really makes a difference when I forget to take it.  Of course, general bone pain is one thing, but I wonder if it would help with joints.  It's wonderful that yoga helped your arm; exercise does seem counterintuitive but it's great how that works. Good luck Christine47!  Port removal and implant exchange is a lot to go through, but you've come a long way.  This short week was nice; I keep thinking how much better each holiday/family event will be next year. Hot flashes can be on schedule?  Good to know ProudMom--hope mine come after five when I start on Tamoxifen later on.  Most of mine so far came mainly with the FEC at the beginning of all this.  I've hardly had any since, though like Betsy says, in this heat it can be hard to tell when your sweating outdoors.  Lake Tahoe sounds wonderful; lucky you!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2011 01:27PM UTMom2014 wrote: Hi everyone, just wanted to share a nutrition-related link from this site.  There is a section on how to cope with food during treatments.  I liked the section on dealing with nausea, and had heard bits and pieces of some things from others. http://www.breastcancer.org/tips/nutrition/index.jsp Hope it helps anyone else who, like me, can't figure out what to eat.  Two skim milk protein shakes and one yogurt so far today. No side effects to speak of and I so want to keep it that way.  Had a cup of ice cream but it didn't taste the same and I found I didn't really want it. Oh well, there goes my biggest vice  JulieH: Thanks for the Miralax tip. I'm seeing my onco on Monday and will check on that and on adding Physllium Husk to shakes for fiber, as another friend also recommended.  Does anyone know if it's ok to continue taking vitamin supplements through chemo?  I haven't got around to seeking approval and just stopped taking a multi-vitamin from a health food store and extra iron.  I will check with the doctor Monday about that.  Too scared to mess with the treatments to do anything without prior approval:D Heard that Michael Douglas kicked his throat cancer but is trying to replace the 30 pounds he lost through the treatments.  That sounds like a lot of weight; could that happen to us?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 12:28PM - edited Jan 16, 2011 12:33PM by UTMom2014 JulieH: I am now on BSN Dessert Lean Chocolate Coconut Protein, as well as Champion Whey Cocoa Mochaccino. My target is to get at least 60-80 grams of protein, as rec by my doctor following the surgery. Most days the milkshake is my breakfast and I have no trouble hitting my target. Both of these brands were recommended elsewhere on this site but I couldn't find the original post.  I got them through netrition.com should your local health places not carry them.  There's soy issues for people who are ER+, so I would be careful.  I did find this article though regarding BS and soy consumption: http://www.breastcancer.org/tips/nutrition/ask_expert/2005_01/question_23.jsp  There's so much to be informed about, but I believe the bc sister who rec these found them to be safe for us.  Regarding protein in general, there is info out there that walnuts and beans slow down the growth of breast cancer and of course, are good sources of protein.  The link below also mentions soy as good for bc, but then there's the ER+ complication.  The best advice I've seen is to go over to the American Cancer Society for info on bc and nutrition.  Ours isn't open after 5 or on weekends, so I do my best online.  Hope these help:D http://ezinearticles.com/?Easy-Ways-to-Prevent-Breast-Cancer&id=3723449 ProudMomandWife:Thanks for the supplement health tips; I'm going to ask my onco tomorrow at my appt!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 02:59PM UTMom2014 wrote: Hello all, I can't believe how much I've missed while away at the hospital this week.  Seems like lots of us are running into rough patches; so sorry that so many of us are suffering.  Being a part of this community definitely helps my moral and attitude.  I'm so grateful to have you all for support and venting:D My WBC dropped to zero Monday, started Nupogen Tuesday and was in the hospital with fever and a mild urinary infection Tuesday nite.  The constant head aches, back pain and hip pain were tough, but everything was so much better by morning after that first night of antibiotics, which I remained on the whole time.  Because I needed Nupogen every day, and because the lab cultures to determine the infection would take two days, my doctor wanted me there 5-7 days, or until I reached a normal state with my WBC.  Thankfully that was today, when I finally reached 9!  Believe it or not the worst part of the experience had to be the constipation, even with all the stuff the hospital gave me.  One of the no-no's if this happens to anyone is no fresh fruits/veggies--so there went my vegetable juice, which together with lots of water and exercise have helped a lot. The other sad part was shedding so much hair while there; I never got a chance to go to the hairdresser because I was feeling so low.  Seeing the shower drain clog up, seeing it on the pillows and even the floor when I walked around was too much for me.  The first stop out of the hospital was a salon where I got a buzz cut.  Thankfully my daughter had remembered to bring my beautiful franceluxe headwrap, and I walked out of there feeling better than I thought I would.  Sending {{{{{hugs}}}}} and good wishes to everyone, too tired to do much today.  My legs feel like jelly and I'm really tired.  Hospitals are no place for a good nights rest, but that's behind me now. Have to concentrate on psyching myself up for FEC#2 next Friday.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2011 04:48PM UTMom2014 wrote: MaryMeg: Your sense of humor is laugh-out-loud funny; may it stay strong through this journey--I know I'll look forward to your posts!  I have a feeling you are a great favorite in your community:D  Aimster1123:  Getting the buzz was easier than I thought because of the shedding on day 15 while at the hospital. My stylist was more shocked than I; being young and never having a female client ask for one, she was reluctant to cut it all off.  I had to say "cancer" two or three times before she relaxed and did it for me.  She made me promise to return once my hair comes back so she can do it for me then:D  AimeeMac: So far the head feels cool, though I've gone through two nights of night sweats.  I wouldn't mind it so much if only I didn't wake up through it.  For me though, a cap after a bath is a must because I'm actually cold there.  The wig on my first full day with it at work was wierd, kept tugging on it.  Like MaryMeg, I worried it would pop off somehow, but I don't know how a gel band would help.  Wouldn't it make it feel tighter?  I just want to get used to it because where I work, someone would be bound to come take my cap/scarf off for grins, and I can't even think about that, lol! So glad Slcst12 and JulieH are feeling better!  Like you guys I'm learning to do all I can on the hi energy days because the low energy days will come round again. May as well make hay while the sun shines.  I too wish for more time before round two; we can mentally hold hands JulieH, because it's just toooo soooon!  I'll be thinking of you:D After the round one weight loss, do you guys feel like this gives us a license to eat whatever?  I indulged in Alfredo sauce w/ravioli and ice cream for lunch today.  At 150 and 5'3" I can afford to lose more but I worry about how much I'll lose over time.  There is a nagging voice telling me to watch the fats though... JeanH: At 50 myself and knee surgery behind me, the coming Nulasta this week makes me nervous. I've got the Claritin, L-Glutamine, and B6/12 going on or in the chemo box ready to go.  Hope that's enough ammunition b/c I don't look forward to more knee pain.  Only time will tell I guess, but eeeek!  Ck-Moma: thanks for the neuropathy study link.  The words "nerve damaging process" chilled my blood.  We need more ammunition against SE's. Hugs to all
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 05:31PM UTMom2014 wrote:  Annie what a nice way to inspire us.  The milestones are a good reminder that this too shall pass and boy am I ready.  Day 5 post #2 finally got here and it was great to eat solids again.  My Laughing Cow wedge w/4 crackers at lunch was just about the best thing I've ever put in my mouth!  As much as I like my protein shake flavors and ice creams, salt is what I absolutely craved. Dinner was a 1/2 portion of Lobster Bisque.  So far no side effects and will branch out more tomorrow.  Light SE's overall all this time, so far anyway. {{{{{fingers crossed}}}}}} baf4292  I love my wig, it's nicer than my own real hair!  Here's a link to the one I got http://www.wigs.com/product_info.php?products_id=3898  It's a Raquel Welch monofilament synthetic wig. The cap is very comfortable and adjusts to your size head.  I liked the bob because of the length, then had it layered to look like I normally wear mine.  The internet sites that carried this style happened to be out of my color, so I called a local shop.  Not only did they carry it, but it was half price!  Since the store is not one of my insurance providers, I was very happy with that price.  My friends and family love it and say it looks like real hair.  I've already washed it once, following all the recommendations for wig care, and it turned out nicely.  The one tip I would give you is get a wide tooth, metal pick to comb it with.  The salesperson was not knowledgeable and I ended up sort of messing up the bottom layer by using a regular brush. I had to trim off bits of it with small sciccors.   The wig care videos on this website are excellent.  I failed to do enough homework at the time and relied on the store clerks.  But if you like your wig, you'll want to protect it. I learned a lot from the care products videos on this site (after the fact).  Hugs to all!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 05:32PM UTMom2014 wrote: Sorry about the quality of the avatar. It looks normal on my computer but looks too small after uploading:(
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2011 04:31PM UTMom2014 wrote: Glad you are doing better JulieH!  It does seem like it's getting a bit tougher some days.  Hope this turns out to be a good, strong week for you.  Something similar with a coworker happened to me with the coughing.  I left my desk and waited til he'd finished up microwaving his lunch.  Yes, I'm the lucky one next to the fridge/micro, but it balances out because I have the window cubicle too.  Anyway, I reached for the Lysol spray and "cleaned" the area, though I had to leave until the spray settled down.  I can't wait for March and the official end of the flu season. About irresistible movies, one of my faves is Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.  Liz Taylor and Paul Newman were just gorgeous back then. Becky,anyone who didn't know about your BC would never guess, you look so healthy and perky in that picture:D Webu: So glad you are feeling better too!  I loved your dog story.  We lost our Shih Tzu last November but I miss him terribly still.  Your story made me wonder how he would have reacted to the sight of my naked head, lol!  I do knit caps and scarves, but also like the commando thing at home too. This was a good day for me; I'm hoping for a strong week.  Tonight I'm baking chocolate rice krispies hearts for a fund-raiser at work.  Got in one mile last night to get rid of what I'm coming to call rubber-hospital-leg-syndrome, which is how they feel after 3+ days there.  It was slow going but my legs were "back" at the end. Planning on doing at least one more tonight.  Sending out positive thoughts to you all:D
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 03:41PM UTMom2014 wrote: FEC X4 @ 3 weeks (#3 today); followed by Taxol X12 @ week   Hi all.  Sorry for the tooth issues, I just can't imagine.  But at least food will be easier for you now:D  Had FEC #3 today; so far so good.  Had ice cream during it, and glad to say my stomach feels better than the two previous ones.  Don't know if it's a temperature thing or just the effect of cream in there?  Had about 2 1/2 cups today, I suppose that's more than enough, but it does make me feel better, so...My family doctor says it's important to keep up the calories and that our bodies metabolize food differently right now, so even though it's a lot of fat (which worries me) it's ok if my body can tolerate it.  In other words, it beats low calorie intake b/c I just can't handle solids for a few days.  Changed my avatar because it was a good day and I still have my eyebrows/lashes.  Is anyone else noticing them slipping off when you wash your face?  My eyelashes in particular...seeing 3-4 almost every time in the evenings for the last few days.  I had hoped they wouldn't go so quickly.  Also, both my thumbs are beginning to show darkening at the base.  I've heard they sometimes go completely black and even fall off.  Sure hope to avoid that, though I also read it doesn't hurt, but it won't be pretty, sigh.... Hope everyone is doing well; I know a few of us were scheduled for chemo today and tomorrow.  Hugs to all; here's to lighter than usual SE's.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 07:02PM UTMom2014 wrote: FEC x4 @3wks/ last one Mr 10; followed by Taxol x12 @week Hi all, two days past #3 and doing better so far than previous two. Worst so far was constipation chased out quickly with prune juice. Too scared to have more but it works wonders.  Chemobrain also becoming more noticeable.  I can't remember names, have to stop and concentrate when getting ready to do something, and double check everything because make careless errors at work all over the place.  The energy level is still decent, but I'm only going for one mile a day now.  Hoping to avoid a third visit to hospital; will get blood levels checked Thursday but if the past is a guide, next Fri is one I'm leary of already.  Hugs to all.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 04:29PM UTMom2014 wrote: FEC X3 @4 wks (one more to go); followed by Taxol X12 @week  Hi all, Is anyone doing anything for their nails?  After FEC 3#, more of the nail beds are darkening.  I seem to remember something about nail hardener and black nail polish to protect them from falling off.  I wonder if any dark color would do the job, whatever it is that black helps with.  I've heard some people end up with nail fungus after all the treatments are over.  One more thing to worry about I guess; got used to losing the hair and wearing a wig, now this.  SLSCT: I'm so sorry about the constipation; it's been a fairly constant se here too.  After #1 stewed prunes with a bit of butter helped a lot. I also used one suppository, the Preparation H cream and wipes (for about three days).   Following round 2 I tried to do the exlax the day of and two days after but ended up drinking prune juice and eating prunes instead.  (Hated taking exlax with the harshness of the chemo too)  Following round 3 I've done just the prune juice and it's been very effective; 1/4 cup every other day is plenty.  Right now I'm just trying to get past the 5-6 tough food days for me.  I'm planning to stay ahead of it better by drinking lots of water, eating 2 prunes daily w/oatmeal and getting at least one mile walked daily.  Hope you get past this and feel better real soon.  Wishing light se's for everyone!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: May 25, 2011 07:59PM UTMom2014 wrote: ProudMom love the happy dance--never seen it before! MaryMeg--don't you love that rush of energy?  No one comes close to describing things as humorously as you though!  All that talent WHILE on chemo, you are amazing:D  I'm glad you got to have a nice send off--my daughter is grown but every major stage and change leaves a mark.  Are you getting that steroid- Decadron-in the pre-meds with Taxol? I can't stand having to take sleeping pills, but the energy rush is great while it lasts.  Between the energy dips and the bone pain that follow, staying in bed is turning into the best option way too often now.   As for the wigs, yup must be that time.  Just replaced mine.    Good luck Melissa and all you ladies doing BMX.  While this doesn't begin to compare, I had a lumpectomy before the chemos started.  As tough as that was, it WAS a breeze compared to the chemicals.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2011 03:34PM UTMom2014 wrote: Proud_Mom congrats on your graduate.  Like you I've had lots of setbacks from low white blood counts.  At this point there's still four weekly Taxol left to get through, woohoo!  It took forever to get past the half way mark.  At this point, I've been getting Neupogen for the fourth week.  I'm now getting it after a 24-hour interval following chemo, to prevent the whites from dropping since it's been a consistent problem from the start. It will be interesting to see how the whites hold up after chemo is over.  Good to see the tips and comments on the radiation.  Personally, I expect it to be easier on the system than this endless chemo.  Has anyone been unable to work due to fatigue from rads? I'm hoping to keep on going, though I've had to take a lot of time off in the last month or so.  Does anyone have eyebrows and eyelashes back yet?  Boy do I miss those!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2011 02:12PM UTMom2014 wrote: Thanks for the suggestions Proud_Mom.  Definitetly love that about this board, cause it's always something.  I seem to remember Yorelh had dental issues towards the end of chemo.  Does anyone know what happens if a tooth has to come out?  Turns out I've had a molar go bad on me, after it was root-canaled several years ago.  Has to come out; currently on antibiotics, no pain yet, thankfully.  Two more chemos to go, and has to happen before radiation as per dentist.  Yep, the fun never stops. Hope you are feeling better JulieH.  I want the port out asap but my doctor wants me to keep it in for TWO years, just in case.  That really bothered me on first hearing about it, and even more now when I see that it's not standard to do that.  When I go to MD Anderson in a couple weeks for post-chemo exams, will def. look into that.  So glad for all of you making it through rads.  I'm right behind you, keeping up the fight.  How is everyone's energy level post chemo?  I'm still able to walk, but nowhere what I used to.  On my 3 or so "bad days" I don't make it past a 1/2 mile if that, on my "strong" days leading up to the next chemo, the most I strive for is 2 miles.  Is it possible or even advised to exercise during radiation?  I've been cursed (yes, cursed) with a D cup since high school and hear larger women have more skin issues.  Not to mention that those of us in hot climes find it challengeing anyway, but this chemo fatigue bugs the heck out of me and walking is the only way I know to beat it back a little. Happy Fourth to all:D
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 09:35AM UTMom2014 wrote: Aimeemac according to my notes from previous year's posts, some take one daily dose of Claritin the day before and for five days following.  I've also read about some girls doing fine with just three days following.  I got my first Neulasta yesterday and so far very little pain; do have a little lower back pain this morning and the 1/2 dose of the liquid Claritin I took helped a lot.  I'm saving the second teaspoon for this afternoon.  There is one BC sister who had a lot of pain on day 6 following Neulasta and got back on it, but she didn't say how many days.  I'm going to do the 5 days and keep my fingers crossed.  Hope this helps you. CK Moma your snow experience is unbelievable.  I'm amazed that you were able to do that and hope this is the last of the crazy weather for you guys in that area.  Where I live it gets to be 90-100+ starting around April or so. I'm worried about the effects of the strong sun and heat, because that's not so good for us either.  All these side effects and weather weirdness to boot, NOT fair Hope everyone has a good weekend.  I'm sticking to shakes and yogurt, so far so good.  Hoping for lighter SE's this second time around following FEC#2.  Was able to work all day Friday; water and exercise seem to be the key.  Of course, my child is 18 and a huge help.  Don't think I could handle being a mom to little ones AND work. Guess that's my tradeoff, which is a blessing in a way because I do have to work.  Hugs to you all
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2011 03:01PM - edited Feb 7, 2011 03:06PM by UTMom2014 Hi all, just back from 3 1/2 days at the hospital.  Not good news, but first: JulieH:Love the new "look"!  We could be twins except my scalp has a few traces of hair left on it:D Ck-Moma:What a bad break, flu following that awful storm, No FAIR!  Hope nothing like that happens again. SherryHuttrs/Webu/Tidenott: I'm for telling family members, especially teenagers.  This is a life-changing situation expecially at that age.  When my daughter went off to UnivTX/Austin last Fall, I thought I would die from missing her and from how suddenly she had such little time for me.  She loves the city, college social events, friends and all that independence.  While she held her own academically, she doesn't yet have the focus she needs to do better.  When I gave her my news and asked she come home this semester b/c I needed her, it was as hard on her as I expected.  The process helped her turn the corner.  It's settled her down so much, she's so worried and has come through when things get tough for me with flying colors.  So Sherry tell you daughter in whatever way works best, it will make a huge difference for her.  I tell mine how she'll always be glad she did this, esp when she's more mature.  Everyone is really proud of how she's risen to the occasion.  Tidenott, I'm so sorry for your loss and just have no words because I can't imagine anything tougher, even this awful cancer.  Webu: I am really happy things turned around with your daughter:D MaryMeg:Happy Belated Birthday!  I'm so glad it was so lovely for you.  We need those joyous moments now more than ever:D bdavis:Have you tried jojoba oil; I hear that's good for itchy scalp.  Mine was mostly sore as it fell off. Now it's almost gone and the soreness has eased up a lot. SunflowerE152:Thanks for the cotton cap tip.  We are mostly super hot and humid down here in South Texas so that is definitely good to know.  I will be trying that one out sooner than I'd like:D  Our winters last all of five minutes, though yes, this year has been unusually cold, brrrrrr. ScienceGirl:I'm with you about a tougher #2 and like you I really dread #3.  I hope you do better! Here's my top five things I learned after this hospitalization.  Though I don't wish this combo on anyone, it may be useful to know. 1.Neulasta does not prevent WBC from dropping.  I learned some people take it weekly; don't know if my dr. will give me that.  Went in at .05, just 8 days following chemo#2.  It's part of that State of Nadir, the 7-10 days following chemo when counts can go off a cliff. 2.Low red counts are life threatening; take temperature when feeling extreme fatigue.  Mine dropped to 7.5; 9 is normal.  I felt like a truck had run over me Thurs after work and thought it was related to stopping the Claritin 5 days following Neulasta as recommended. Had near screaming-point back pain, tiredness, headache, and just not feeling well.  Temperature at noon when I gave up trying to recover strength (after staying in bed Friday) was 102.3.  Rec'd blood transfusion right away; came up to 9.  Dr's explained organs must have oxygen provided by the reds so it really was critical to get attention right away. 3.Avoid fresh fruits and veggies.  I'm not allowed my raw veggie juices until I get done with next two FEC's.  The microbes can do real damage when counts are low and I'm sick to death of the hospital.  I hate to give up raw veggies, but this is too important.  I can live on cooked for the next 8 weeks. 4.Avoid crowds, sick people and practice good hygiene.  This is a toughie, I get stir crazy; my outings are walks in the neighborhood.  I still visit my dad at his nursing home but only once a week now and only outside in the patio when weather permits.  I'm terrified of going in that building now. 5.Work and exercise did not cause any of this.  After going over all possible things I could do to prevent this in the future, all of the doctors said this would have happened even if I'd stayed in bed and never gotten in any exercise.  Chemo kills both bad and good cells.  We all cope differently with the effects and this is mine.  There are no guarantee's I won't be there again after #'s 3, and 4.  On the bright side, Phase 2 for me is 12 weekly Taxol.  This is not expected to happen through those, though I might need Nupogens in between sometimes.  I need to get through this phase before I can think about any of that at this point. This group continues to be a huge difference in my life.  Your wisdom, wit, strength and inspiration are really important to me.  Be well; sending out lots  of cyber {{{{{{hugs}}}}}} !
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2011 08:24PM UTMom2014 wrote: Finally on the other side of #3 without hospitalization, but it sure knocked me off my feet.  Dizzyness was def. a problem this time.  Had to stay in bed since Wed night and only really got up today.  One more day of recovery, just in case, then finally back to work and hopefully normalcy on Tuesday.  Dr. has delayed #4 one more week, wants to be sure my counts are up to the challenge.  I'll be keeping up to see if #4 is easier than #3 for those of us approaching it soon.  Seems like lots of us were in chemo hell for this one.  Lots of luck to everyone heading for the final one, I'll be right behind you.  Watching the Oscars and loved this Lena Horne quote: "It's not the load that breaks you down, it's the way you carry it."  While I had most of my teary bouts at the beginning while trying to accept and adjust to the changes, I give you guys a lot of credit for finding the strength to carry it with a stronger spirit.  Were it not for the BC, I doubt this quote would have the meaning for me it does.  I wonder when/if connecting everday occurences to BC will fade away.  {{{Hugs}}} to all as we head into another week of this.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2011 10:17AM UTMom2014 wrote:

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2011 03:32PM UTMom2014 wrote: AimeeMac--Yaayyy!  One more of us done; I'm a week behind but can't wait to be in your shoes! baf4292--Glad for you too!   It's got to be the best "light at the end of the tunnel" experience I've ever had! MaryMeg: Thanks for the giggles; glad your sense of humor is intact--we sure benefit from it!  I've been able to handle work for about 5 days following chemo. It sounds from your fitness levels like this should be really do-able for you.  I work for a Dept of Justice agency here along the southern U.S. border. Every once in a while something about what we are dealing with makes it past all the celebrity gossip; needless to say we are busy enough to have to work weekends when necessary.  I've had to work for a full 5 days following #3 (through weekend) and have another full weekend on schedule following #4 next Thurs.  It's the state of nadir (days 6-11 or so) that give me trouble. tsundermann/lorenar:  Infections/flu at a time like this can't be good--so sorry.  My doctor pretty much wants me straight home following work to avoid crowds and flu. Low white blood counts have been a consistent problem for me during state of nadir.  Texas has a pretty big outbreak going on and I'v have a cold coming on since yesterday.  My onco gave me permission to take Zicam, which worked really well back in Oct. when I started to get one.  Hoping to avoid a full out case of flu. I'm off to make a pot of chicken soup loaded with garlic and onions--my favorite anti-cold medicine since childhood!  Here's to a great weekend and light SE's for all.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2011 05:20PM UTMom2014 wrote: christine47:  It may have to do with that person's white or red blood cells dropping, especially during state of nadir (7-10 days following chemo), as is the case with me.  Since #2, my onco has me on only cooked or canned veggies and foods; there's danger of infection from microbes.  I really miss fresh veggies, but it'll be behind me soon enough. This may not be necessary for you and I really hope this isn't your situation.   So happy for everyone who is done--wonderful news!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 07:34PM UTMom2014 wrote: Congrats to all finishing up Phase I.  Has anyone used ice bags on feet and hands to ward off neuropathy during Taxol?  I think B.Davis mentioned it; have heard it prevents the chemo from settleing there and wards of problems.  I'm having first one April 1; my doctor said it was ok to try it.  Will be looking into the l-glutamine.  Thanks for posting taxol experiences, it helps to know what it can be like.  This is so tough, but we will survive this.  I'm borrowing an idea from another bc survivor who bought lotto scratch-off's for chemo day. Think I'll do the same, and have at least one little thing to look forward to those days, plus have a way of counting down the 12 treatments.  I'd rather go on a trip, but work is too busy.  Most times I head to Miami where I have family that I love being with, plus it's really beautiful there.  Hoping to make time for a trip this year when I should be recovered and AFTER hurricane season ends!  Here's to a good weekend for all.  I'm dealing with post #4 and though I'm "done", it'll be a week and a half or so before I clear the bad stuff.  Friends want to join me for drinks once I can handle normal food/liquids to CELEBRATE.  I'm really happy to be here but still have state of nadir ahead and just a bit apprehensive because of what it's like.  {{{{Hugs/prayers to all}}}}
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2011 07:06PM UTMom2014 wrote: Warrior Princess: I hope the Gabapentin helps.  So far the L-Glutamine supplement (I'm only doing 15 mg a day) has been helping me with the (so far) tingling of the feet mostly.  Another tip I got here was to keep hands and feet on ice bags during the taxol infusion.  It's supposed to prevent the Taxol from pooling there and minimizes nueropathy.  So far I've just done it with my hands but after #2 of 12 last week, I felt it more in my feet.  I do remember reading that the SE's get more intense after #6.  Hang in there, you are almost done with the Taxol.  I'm getting more nervous with each one and I really sympathize.  Feel better soon.  Congrats to all the chemo grads!  Like some here, I too have 5-6 week ahead of rads after that.  Will keep up with you guys b/c I'm interested in learning more about what happens with the tamox and the chemo pause stuff.  My period tapered off after two during the first two months of chemo.  Anybody seeing swelling in the hands or anywhere else with Taxol?  The constipation just won't quit either, but I'm now used to trying to stay ahead of it.  So far no bone pain, but I keep waiting for it to hit.  Wishing everyone light SE's as we hit the homestretch.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2011 07:01PM UTMom2014 wrote: Hi all, I'm with you guys on the exercise but hoping for advice here.  My white blood count went down to zero as of a CBC done today.  Like some of you, I had to show need before Neulasta was considered.  If insurance covers Nupogen,I'll get one shot daily until Friday; another CBC next week and then weekly, since I'm having trouble already.  In the meantime, I'm on isolation, cooked foods, freq hand washing/lots fo hygeine issues.  Even our 8-wk Weimeraner has to go elsewhere while all this clears (have to avoid the germs and he's not yet housebroken).  So many sudden complications, I feel like I've been hit by a truck.  Plus, my period intensified today, so not feeling too wonderful but still able to get around.  Thankfully I kept myself home all weekend thinking the onset of my period was causing back pain and low energy. I did get two miles in yesterday but got a headache afterwards that lasted all day.  Today I had two dr appts and was around several people with colds/viruses.  Of course, I quickly got away from them, but I don't know.  My dr. says exercise if I feel up to it, but one article I found online says avoid all exercise if you are neutropenic.  Anyone here know anything about this?  I'm staying home from work, not worth the risk of ending up in the hospital.  I read about one poor girl who ended up on life support due to infection while neutropenic.  I'm putting all this on here should anyone else not be aware of this possiblility.  I knew that low blood counts might crop up, but just didn't expect it this soon.  Apparently the chemo does a number on our bone marrow, and apparently there is a high number of us who will go into the hospital at least once during chemo because of that.  A BC sister on another thread regarding Nupogena mentioned it but didn't know the statistic.  I'm interested in continueing to walk and resuming weight lifting.  I can only handle two pounds weights still because of the lumpectomy.  This stuff has scared me silly today and I'm waiting to learn more before I do so.  As someone else here said, there doesn't seem to be anything linear about this process.  I really hope no one else among us has to go through this, but the odds are against it.   Please take care of yourselves and avoid crowds;infection is nothing to fool with.  Hugs to everyone.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2011 07:41PM UTMom2014 wrote: Thanks everyone for you words of support!  Today has been great.  JulieH your prunes with butter tip did the trick--I will be doing that one daily because I don't ever want to be in that place again:D  Really got moving today: 2 mile walk and one hour salsa fitness via YouTube.  I've been paying close attention to everyone's issues with Neulasta, since that's next week.  JeanH I've read that Claritin the day before and for 5 days after is very helpful and have stocked up.  I've also been taking B6/B12 since I learned I'd be getting it.  L-Glutamine is on the shopping list, since it's helped so many of our sisters avoid the bone pain everyone talks about. Have any of you girls who've experienced the Neulasta shot already had it in the stomach?  Just wondering because there is so much less pain felt there.  While receiving Nupogen in the hospital, one athletic nurse suggested the stomach because of the fat there.  He told me that it hurts more when it hits muscle in the arm and says there is much less fat in the arms.  He was right, the burn/sting of the medicine was probalby only half as bad. I'm going to see if I can get the Neulasta there as well.  BTW guys, here's a cute video I caught at the hospital from Good Morning America.  In it, Louis Van Amstel of Dancing With the Stars shows Robin Roberts and others the Twist and says 3-5 minutes of this dance daily takes care of abs.  It's certainly a fun way to work the stomach, for those days when crunches aren't too exciting.  I looked up Chubby Checker on Youtube and had fun this morning--music is such a good mood lifter:D http://www.tvsquad.com/2011/01/21/robin-roberts-dances-the-twist-on-gma-video/ Thinking of everyone and sending out good thoughts for improved health and strong spirits!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: May 10, 2011 02:52PM - edited May 10, 2011 02:53PM by UTMom2014 Congrats B.Davis on the end of the journey and all recent chemo grads as well!  Warrior Princess,So sorry about how rough it's been.  I hope things get better for you. I'm with you on looking into stopping treatment.  I'm on my 5th delay due to low Whites, with 5 day series of Neupogen shots (again) to help/hurt with awful bone pain.  I just got past a month series of weekly iron infusions to keep my reds healthy, but trending down again just one week out.  Waiting for labs to see if I have to repeat that series.  Does anyone know anything about what this means during Taxol, when blood counts should be more stable than through DD treatments?  I'm barely past #4, and had FECX4 @3wks. As always, so grateful for this thread; just read the conversation here regarding scans which I thought were required.  I do hear there are dangers of doing more scans than necessary.  You guys are making me see that they may not be needed, though I had a lumpectomy, so I will be asking my onco about that.  Feeling not so great still so switching to 1/2 days at work starting tomorrow.  I'm hoping to get a bit more rest, and how can that be bad?  My husband, who has been great through all this, is asking me to stop work completely, but I'm having a hard time "giving in" to cancer to that degree. What I read about the hard time many have towards the end of Taxol makes me think I may well expect to be home full time, at least at the end of this.  Again, so happy for everyone wrapping up this leg of the journey! Hugs to all:D
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2011 09:35AM UTMom2014 wrote: AimeeMac, Marial and Yorelh Congrats on your good news!  So happy for you and wish you guys the best as you move on to better health:D  I wonder if it will be a little like after childbirth, where you just want to focus on the "baby/good health" and try to put the hard road you traveled behind you?  This is way more complicated and difficult than having a baby, so I guess it will be harder to put it completely out of our heads. May all our rewards for having undergone this path be just as long-lasting and positive.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward
